talk.summaryAsHtml: How do you give users of your mobile app the best possible experience? One where they can share data with other users and where their settings, preferences, progress, etc are the same regardless of the device that they use to access the app? In this session, through the use of Java and Android code examples and live demos, we show how simple it is to build storage features into your mobile apps through the use of mobile Cloud services such as the recently announced Google Cloud Save, and look at how easy it is to build custom mobile backends that integrate with these mobile Cloud Services to allow for various different forms of in-app messaging, data sharing and analytics.
talk.title: Are your mobile users well connected? Storing and sharing data in the cloud with Mobile Backend Services and Firebase
talk.summary: How do you give users of your mobile app the best possible experience? One where they can share data with other users and where their settings, preferences, progress, etc are the same regardless of the device that they use to access the app? In this session, through the use of Java and Android code examples and live demos, we show how simple it is to build storage features into your mobile apps through the use of mobile Cloud services such as the recently announced Google Cloud Save, and look at how easy it is to build custom mobile backends that integrate with these mobile Cloud Services to allow for various different forms of in-app messaging, data sharing and analytics.

talk.summaryAsHtml: With less than five years and three releases under its belt, CDI has proven itself to be a great asset for Java. The many features it provides (dependency injection, contextual lifecycle, configuration, interception, event notification, and more) and the innovative way it provides them (through the use of meta-annotations) explain its rapid adoption. This session reviews the features introduced in CDI 1.1 and 1.2 and discusses improvements planned for CDI 2, such as standard support for Java SE and a light CDI version useful for embedded environments, showing how it will benefit Java.
talk.title: The path to CDI 2.0
talk.summary: With less than five years and three releases under its belt, CDI has proven itself to be a great asset for Java. The many features it provides (dependency injection, contextual lifecycle, configuration, interception, event notification, and more) and the innovative way it provides them (through the use of meta-annotations) explain its rapid adoption. This session reviews the features introduced in CDI 1.1 and 1.2 and discusses improvements planned for CDI 2, such as standard support for Java SE and a light CDI version useful for embedded environments, showing how it will benefit Java.

talk.summaryAsHtml: Java 8 is of course the release of lambda expressions, the Stream API and the Collectors class. This major release shadows everything. But Java 8 has many more gems in many fields: a new API for dates, a new ConcurrentHashMap, a new HashMap, new concurrency utilities, a new JavaScript engine, a new version of JavaFX, and all kinds of little things that will make our lives easier, and that we present here. The goal of this presentation is to show as many new things as possible, readily available as soon as our project have moved to Java 8.
talk.title: 50 new things we can do with Java 8
talk.summary: Java 8 is of course the release of lambda expressions, the Stream API and the Collectors class. This major release shadows everything. But Java 8 has many more gems in many fields: a new API for dates, a new ConcurrentHashMap, a new HashMap, new concurrency utilities, a new JavaScript engine, a new version of JavaFX, and all kinds of little things that will make our lives easier, and that we present here. The goal of this presentation is to show as many new things as possible, readily available as soon as our project have moved to Java 8.

talk.summaryAsHtml: Web entrepreneurship and ICT have an enormous, yet not fully exploited potential for accelerating the digital economy and thus transforming the knowledge society. Several barriers (from access to finance, difficulties in scaling up, lack of business skills and market fragmentation) affect the creation of sustainable businesses. To address these challenges the European Commission (EC) has launched several initiatives such as the European Programme for Internet enabled innovation (FI-PPP) which aims to boost the development and adoption of Future Internet technologies and increase the effectiveness of web based businesses.SOUL-FI (Startups Optimizing Urban Life with Future Internet) is one of 16 technology accelerator projects funded by the EC under FP7 within the FI-PPP programme. It will offer dedicated funding and mentoring services to translate innovative ideas (new apps and services) into pilot products backed by a robust and investor-ready business model.
talk.title: SOUL FI technology accelerator: funding and support services for boosting future internet solutions for a smarter urban life
talk.summary:
Web entrepreneurship and ICT have an enormous, yet not fully exploited potential for accelerating the digital economy and thus transforming the knowledge society.
Several barriers (from access to finance, difficulties in scaling up, lack of business skills and market fragmentation) affect the creation of sustainable businesses. To address these challenges the European Commission (EC) has launched several initiatives such as the European Programme for Internet enabled innovation (FI-PPP) which aims to boost the development and adoption of Future Internet technologies and increase the effectiveness of web based businesses.SOUL-FI (Startups Optimizing Urban Life with Future Internet) is one of 16 technology accelerator projects funded by the EC under FP7 within the FI-PPP programme. It will offer dedicated funding and mentoring services to translate innovative ideas (new apps and services) into pilot products backed by a robust and investor-ready business model.

talk.summaryAsHtml: Top legal tips for indie developers working on apps for clients, based on the very expensive mistakes I made in my first 5 years of developing apps for clients.
talk.title: Legal Considerations For Contract Developers A Cautionary Tale
talk.summary: Top legal tips for indie developers working on apps for clients, based on the very expensive mistakes I made in my first 5 years of developing apps for clients.

talk.summaryAsHtml:
For over a decade, the component oriented MVC offered by JSF has been the sole user interface technology in the Java EE platform. All the while, action oriented MVC, as embodied in non-standard technologies such as Spring MVC and Struts, has been hugely popular and productive. This session introduces the MVC 1.0 specification which is intended to fill this hole in the Java EE platform

The session starts by reviewing the industry trends that have brought us to this point. We begin with an explanation about the differences between component oriented MVC and action oriented MVC. These two approaches have evolved in parallel, yet share a server-oriented approach to managing UI complexity. At the same time, more capable browsers have made it desirable to move a greater portion of the UI complexity from the server to the browser. We examine how MVC 1.0 is well suited to a world where UI complexity resides more and more in the browser.

From the context of industry trends, the session continues by offering a window on the work-in-progress of the MVC 1.0 specification. Particular attention will be paid to how MVC 1.0 integrates with the rest of JavaEE, CDI, Bean Validation and JSF.
talk.title: MVC 1.0 (JSR 371)
talk.summary:
For over a decade, the component oriented MVC offered by JSF has been
the sole user interface technology in the Java EE platform.  All the while, 
action oriented MVC, as embodied in non-standard technologies such as
Spring MVC and Struts, has been hugely popular and productive. This
session introduces the MVC 1.0 specification which is intended to fill this
hole in the Java EE platform

The session starts by reviewing the industry trends that have brought us
to this point.  We begin with an explanation about the differences
between component oriented MVC and action oriented MVC.  These two
approaches have evolved in parallel, yet share a server-oriented
approach to managing UI complexity.  At the same time, more capable
browsers have made it desirable to move a greater portion of the UI
complexity from the server to the browser.  We examine how MVC 1.0 is
well suited to a world where UI complexity resides more and more in the
browser.

From the context of industry trends, the session continues by offering a
window on the work-in-progress of the MVC 1.0 specification. Particular 
attention will be paid to how MVC 1.0 integrates with the rest of JavaEE,
CDI, Bean Validation and JSF.

talk.summaryAsHtml:
For 10 years, Groovy has dramatically improved the productivity of Java developers on the desktop. With unique like closures, builders, AST transformations, traits, static compilation and many more, Groovy turned out to be a very competitive language on the JVM. Compared to other JVM languages, Groovy has the major advantage of being totally Java-friendly, both in terms of syntax and interoperability.

But during those years, what happened on the mobile world? In particular, Android developers are used to develop applications in Java, so why Groovy, a JVM language, wouldn't be usable for Android development too? Can we ease the pain of Android developers?

In this session, we will demonstrate how you can develop an Android application using the Groovy language. We will show what advantages it offers, what features you can rely on to improve your productivity on this platform, as you did with Groovy on the desktop. We will talk about the advantages of using Groovy, but also the drawbacks and current limitations. In particular, if you're jealous of your Apple friends using Swift to develop iOS applications, be ready to love programming again!
talk.title: Android and Groovy, a winning pair?
talk.summary:
For 10 years, Groovy has dramatically improved the productivity of Java developers on the desktop. With unique like closures, builders, AST transformations, traits, static compilation and many more, Groovy turned out to be a very competitive language on the JVM. Compared to other JVM languages, Groovy has the major advantage of being totally Java-friendly, both in terms of syntax and interoperability.

But during those years, what happened on the mobile world? In particular, Android developers are used to develop applications in Java, so why Groovy, a JVM language, wouldn't be usable for Android development too? Can we ease the pain of Android developers?

In this session, we will demonstrate how you can develop an Android application using the Groovy language. We will show what advantages it offers, what features you can rely on to improve your productivity on this platform, as you did with Groovy on the desktop. We will talk about the advantages of using Groovy, but also the drawbacks and current limitations. In particular, if you're jealous of your Apple friends using Swift to develop iOS applications, be ready to love programming again!

talk.summaryAsHtml: The recent unveiling of Android Wear introduced a brand new set of challenges and opportunities for application designers and developers. Indeed, wearable computing requires designers to think in a radically different manner while offering tremendous new ways to improve people lives. This session acts as a complete overview of the new Android Wear ecosystem and explains how developers can push their existing apps to the wearable level from both a designer and a developer perspective.
talk.title: Introduction to Android Wear - A Glimpse Into the Future
talk.summary: The recent unveiling of Android Wear introduced a brand new set of challenges and opportunities for application designers and developers. Indeed, wearable computing requires designers to think in a radically different manner while offering tremendous new ways to improve people lives. This session acts as a complete overview of the new Android Wear ecosystem and explains how developers can push their existing apps to the wearable level from both a designer and a developer perspective.

talk.summaryAsHtml: Continuous deployment is causing organizations to rethink how they build and release software. Atlassian Bamboo is rapidly adding features to help with automating deployment, but there are a lot of other practical and organizational issues that need to be addressed when adopting this development model. The Atlassian business platforms team has been dealing with these issues over the last few months as it transitions the company’s order system to continuous deployment. This presentation covers why the team adopted this model, some of challenges it encountered, and the approaches and tools it used to overcome them.
talk.title: Practical Continuous Deployment
talk.summary: Continuous deployment is causing organizations to rethink how they build and release software. Atlassian Bamboo is rapidly adding features to help with automating deployment, but there are a lot of other practical and organizational issues that need to be addressed when adopting this development model. The Atlassian business platforms team has been dealing with these issues over the last few months as it transitions the company’s order system to continuous deployment. This presentation covers why the team adopted this model, some of challenges it encountered, and the approaches and tools it used to overcome them.

talk.summaryAsHtml:
For a number of reasons, it has been extremely difficult to run standard Java applications on mobile devices (e.g. smartphones and tablets). Most of the cross-platform solutions so far were based on non-standard API's. Today, that situation has changed. RoboVM and LodgON show that you can use your existing Java applications that run on desktops and package them as native applications for iOS and Android, using the JavaFX API's that are part of the Java 8 Platform, Standard Edition. There is no need to learn new languages or API's, or to port your application to every single platform you want to support. You can use the open-source SDK's and publish your JavaFX application to the AppStore and the Play Store.

With the rise of mobile devices, and the growing popularity of native applications on those mobile devices, this means that the target market for Java developers is growing as well.
talk.title: Real cross-platform Java on mobile devices
talk.summary:
For a number of reasons, it has been extremely difficult to run standard Java applications on mobile devices (e.g. smartphones and tablets). Most of the cross-platform solutions so far were based on non-standard API's.
Today, that situation has changed. RoboVM and LodgON show that you can use your existing Java applications that run on desktops and package them as native applications for iOS and Android, using the JavaFX API's that are part of the Java 8 Platform, Standard Edition.
There is no need to learn new languages or API's, or to port your application to every single platform you want to support. You can use the open-source SDK's and publish your JavaFX application to the AppStore and the Play Store.

With the rise of mobile devices, and the growing popularity of native applications on those mobile devices, this means that the target market for Java developers is growing as well.

talk.summaryAsHtml: The new lambda language features in Java SE 8 are catalysts for new APIs that would previously have been impractical or impossible. The Streams API, which enables bulk operations on collections and other aggregates, sequentially or in parallel, is one such example that is the centrepiece of the Java SE 8 libraries. This session, primarily via the IDE and Java tooling, examines the Stream API, architecture, and implementation in detail so that developers can learn how to use the API, get good performance and scalability, and apply the same design techniques to their own APIs.
talk.title: In Full Flow: Java 8 Lambdas in the Stream
talk.summary: The new lambda language features in Java SE 8 are catalysts for new APIs that would previously have been impractical or impossible. The Streams API, which enables bulk operations on collections and other aggregates, sequentially or in parallel, is one such example that is the centrepiece of the Java SE 8 libraries. This session, primarily via the IDE and Java tooling, examines the Stream API, architecture, and implementation in detail so that developers can learn how to use the API, get good performance and scalability, and apply the same design techniques to their own APIs.

talk.summaryAsHtml: As tech professionals, what we need is a way to work better so that we can create more, right? In order to have more creative productivity, we need to hack how we use our brains on a daily basis in order to access more of its inherent processing and creative power. Through exploring various concepts and approaches, including the neuroscience of creativity, productivity techniques, and emerging practices that spur innovation, we'll discover not only the ways in which our brains work best, but also what’s behind the times when we feel on fire with creativity and when we don't. We’ll translate this information into processes and techniques for dramatically enhanced creative productivity. Beware: this talk may change how you work…for the better.
talk.title: Hacking the Creative Brain
talk.summary: As tech professionals, what we need is a way to work better so that we can create more, right? In order to have more creative productivity, we need to hack how we use our brains on a daily basis in order to access more of its inherent processing and creative power. Through exploring various concepts and approaches, including the neuroscience of creativity, productivity techniques, and emerging practices that spur innovation, we'll discover not only the ways in which our brains work best, but also what’s behind the times when we feel on fire with creativity and when we don't. We’ll translate this information into processes and techniques for dramatically enhanced creative productivity. Beware: this talk may change how you work…for the better.

talk.summaryAsHtml: Memory leaks and other memory exhaustion situations are frequent enemies of Java application developers and administrators. They can crash your application or make it unbearably slow. This tutorial explains different ways to monitor the memory usage of Java applications and how to distinguish between normal and critical situations. It also addresses what information is necessary and when and how to collect it to start solving memory-usage-related problems in your application. You’ll also learn what a memory dump is and how to use it. The presentation also briefly discusses what class loader leaks are and how they differ from object leaks. The session ends with a brief discussion of what other tools are available and if they are useful.
talk.title: Where Is my memory?
talk.summary: Memory leaks and other memory exhaustion situations are frequent enemies of Java application developers and administrators. They can crash your application or make it unbearably slow. This tutorial explains different ways to monitor the memory usage of Java applications and how to distinguish between normal and critical situations. It also addresses what information is necessary and when and how to collect it to start solving memory-usage-related problems in your application. You’ll also learn what a memory dump is and how to use it. The presentation also briefly discusses what class loader leaks are and how they differ from object leaks. The session ends with a brief discussion of what other tools are available and if they are useful.
